text: Sample at Kuhnhenn on 12/11/16. Listed as a braggot vs. a Scotch ale. Clear amber pour with a medium off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel and honey. Malty and caramelly flavor with a sweet honey finish.

The aroma, this may sound silly, smells like when you walk into Founders Brewing, a bright red robust roast malt with a hint of sweet prune, and some bitter oak on the end. Appears clear dark ruby red, light caramel foam. Tastes like toffee and caramel had a drunkin threeway with a date, very sweet and warm. Feels a little oily, but generally light. Overall, toffee, toffee, toffee - very nice barrell aging flavor.
Tap. Dark brown. Nice tan bubbles. Nose of malt mash -- sort of like walking into a brewery. Smooth. Mellow bourbon sweetness followed by smooth chocolate malt character. Very nice.
Pours a dark mahogany with a white head. Has a caramel, bread, and fruit aroma. Flavor is similar, with some sweet bourbon and vanilla notes. Quite good.
Bottle @ home ... trade from Fullobs... thx my friend...vintage 2012... It pours dark brown with a small tan head.... dark fruits, nuts, liquor, bourbon, fruity, punch, caramel and oak.... very nice

On tap. 
Weak head, aromas of bacon, ham, deli meat. deep red color.
Taste is fruity, punch, aftertaste that lingers is one if crisp apple, and cherry.
Best Scottish Ale Ive tasted hutherto.

12 oz bottle thanks to Crajun. Poured a beautiful deep amber into a snifter. Huge nose of candy, dark fruit, caramel & booze. Big malt forward flavor, the peat is subtle but the boozy sugars are quite present. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 12oz bottle in a thistle. Pours deep ruby/brown with a cream-colored head. Aroma of chocolate and toffee and cereal from the malts, some bourbon and oak, slightly roasted malts, hints of vanilla and spices, and some light dough. Flavor the same with a nice blend of it all. Smooth, thicker texture.

Truly tasty. The aroma was sweet with oak and bourbon. Dark burgundy as the description suggests with a thin head. Smooth and velvety with good weight. The carbonation was appropriate. Great blend of strong flavors with sweet burnt malts, woody and bourbon. The bitterness was not high but just enough. Great after-dinner drink. Alcohol was well hidden. A must try.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2015 Tap: Deep ruby & mahogany tones all around with a super small spattering of gray & khaki-tinted bubbles sifting along the top. Aroma packed with fruity esters, grapes, dates, plums, red apple skins, & mild back-end anise. Hidden underneath is a solid helping of toasty toffee, mild nuts, & a hint of peppery phenol, likely from the yeast. Taste hits with sweet malt & brash yeast up front; toffee, licorice, plums, lightly vinous grape skins, faint molasses... Finish is more yeast heavy with white pepper, spicy & fruit esters, & mild phenol. Lots of sticky toffee & a hint of nuttiness in the finish. Reminds me of a Scotch ale that uses Belgian yeast. Solid.
355ml bottle shared by jsprime. amber with almost no head. under carbed. a solid if uninteresting big amber ale. punches below its weight.

12 ounce bottle thanks to umich03jm. Thanks! Pours a dark amber with a beige head of foam that dies down at a moderate rate. The aroma has a ton of malt character. Sweet caramel, some booze, toffee. Taste is more of the same with big notes of caramel and toffee, but theres also some dark fruit character here as well. As it develops in the glass, it really mellows out and gets that raisin and fig characteristic that I love from old English Barleywines like Thomas Hardys. The mouthfeel on this is smooth and chewy with a lower carbonation. Mouthcoating without being heavy.

12 oz from umich03. Deep brown color with a red hue. Aroma is a little bourbon with some wood an vanilla. Flavor is smooth and candi sugar caramel. Deep rich flavors. Smooth and subtle nice. Good scotch ale base beer with that flat cola flavor I love. Been liking for this for a while and it was worth the wait.
12oz to snifter. Dark brown but crystal clear. Very minimal carbonation. Sweet and syrupy. Malty delicious. Maybe even a little root beer. Subtle barrel aging. Alcohol well hidden. Delicious.

2012 bottle recd in trade from umichjo3. This is a notch or two below Founders backwwods and Rahr Iron Thishtle in my book. The aroma was caramel, alcohol, and sherry -wtf?? nice palate. Taste was malty but not sweet with a much malt. ever so slight sherry at end that is just out of place??

Bottle 2012 on the rear of the label. Pour has a dark brown color and a ring of off white head that fell right away. Aroma has rich browm malt, earth, nuts, dark brown sugar, oak, and sweet bourbon. Mouth feel is medium and the carbonation is extremely light. Flavor has some sweet bourbon upfront, old oak, dark brown sugar, rich malt, raisin, and a bit of oxidation. Really a big beer with a lot of richness and plenty brought in from the barrels.

12 ounce bottle into signature tulip glass, 2012 Winter solstice bottling. Pours very hazy and cloudy deep ruby red color with a small foamy head that lasts a second, and reduces to a thin lacing ring. Minimal lacing on the glass. Aromas of big caramel, toast, brown sugar, raisin, prune, apple, pear, toffee, brown bread, tobacco, light pepper, leather, herbal, light nuttiness, light chocolate, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of malt and fruity notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, brown sugar, toast, toffee, raisin, pear, apple, prune, tobacco, brown bread, leather, herbal, light pepper, light nuttiness, light chocolate, and yeast earthiness. Lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, toast, toffee, raisin, prune, pear, apple, brown bread, light chocolate, herbal, tobacco, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Awesome balance and complexity of malt and fruity flavors; with zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a slick and fairly syrupy mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is an excellent scotch ale! Great complexity of malt and fruity flavors; and quite smooth to sip on. A very enjoyable offering.

2012 bottle. Pours a brownish orange with no head. Intense aroma of apple cider and slight alcohol. Taste matches aroma and is quite sweet. Mouthfeel is medium with no carbonation. I don't taste any alcohol at 11%. Reminds me of apple cider with no tangy bite. More like a strong juice than a beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle received via trade with FlandersNed.  Pours lightly hazy brown with a small, fizzy light tan head, short retention with no lacing.  Aroma is caramel and toast malt, earthy hops, dates and figs with some oxidized sherry notes.  Flavor is sweet and caramelized malt, faint hops and bitterness, lightly tart with dark dried fruits and a sweet finish.  Full body and light carbonation.

Bottle. Pours murky brown with thin, fuzzy white head; short retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is caramel and cookie malts, figs, dates, light toffee, floral hops, and faint toast. Flavor is sweet, bready malts forward with supporting dark fruit esters, floral notes, light spicy hops, and faint toast; dry, lightly sweet finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle thanks to my mom. Pours a clear deep amber grayish tan head that dissipates completely. Aroma has notes of musty grain and cereal with a bit of bourbon and raisin. Flavor has more raisin with some sweet grains and a bourbon.

Bottle for rating #4900: &nbsp Deep and dark caramel, thin tannish head, sudsy, spotty lacing. &nbsp Meaty nose of peat and campfire, some ash and charred wood. &nbsp Also some fig/date. &nbsp More fruity on the tongue than most, has a slight prunish tinge to it. &nbsp The peat and ash dont seem as strong on the tongue as the nose suggested. &nbsp As it warms I get very faint vanilla and toffee/caramel notes, likely from the bourbon barrel aging. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are 
moderate. &nbsp Doesnt capture me as a big or hefty example, but its better than most. &nbsp Its more fruity for sure, and the backside has a slight sour tinge to it. &nbsp Decent overall, but not what I was hoping for based on the reviews. &nbsp Seems fairly average to me.

Dark burgundy, no head. Nose is light sour apple, toffee, caramel, barrel. Taste is huge caramel apple, banana, vanilla, toffee, light maple syrup. Slightly boozy finish with a light lingering sweetness. Silky mouthfeel.

Pours cola brown. Aromas of brown sugar, and caramel, light spice. Flavor is bread dough malty with caramel and butter browned brown sugar.  Wonderful roasted goodness with notes of dark fruit.  Hints of chocolate and honey.  Roasted malty awesomeness.  Body is on the fuller side, rich and creamy. Cant  imagine a scotch ale being much better than this!

Pours dark brown with almost no head. Aroma is sweet malt, bread, licorice, peat, and white grapes. Taste is white grapes, spice, figs, and a splash of booze. Dangerously drinkable and a fine example of a scotch ale.

This one poured a semi murky lighter brown color with a beige head.  Aroma was of burnt caramel, some light barrel, and dark fruits.  Falvor was midly peated, dark fruits, nice roasted notes withing being astringent. Really nice big example of the style.

From the March 2013 3R6P tasting. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a hazy dark brown color with a small foamy tan head that left decent lacing. The aroma was uncooked bread dough, pretzel and a bit of cherry. The flavor was sour caramel with a medicinal presence and a malty middle with hints of honey and uncooked bread dough. Medium length finish. Moderately full bodied with well concealed alcohol. Solid.

Drink this cold. Almost no carbonation. There is little to no lacing in my glass but there is some sediment floating around. The scent is of carmel malts, slight wood characteristics from barrel aging, dried fruits, and a mild sweet bourbon aroma. The flavor has a sweetness to it with a slight bitter and dry finish. The sweet bourbon is not heavy but noticeable and adds just the right amount of flavor. The bourbon, medium to heavy sweet carmel malts, and dark fruits work nicely together to hide the alcohol taste. Overall I enjoyed this beverage it was a nice experience.

Tap at Barcade.. Pour is a clear red/brown. Aroma is whisky, candied dark fruit, caramel. Taste is sweet whiskey, malt, woos, leather, dark fruit. A tad boozy but really easy to drink. A nice scotch ale.

12oz bottle, 2012 vintage, thanks to umich03jm. Bottle is labeled as 11% alcohol, and has no mention of bourbon barrel aging, but the label says right on front "A Few Shillings Too Many Ale" and there is no other beer by that name in the database right now. Dark red / brown color. Hazy with the many particles suspended in the body. Minimal khaki / tan head, fades quickly to very little. Bigger body. Lighter carbonation. More dry overall, nothing sticky. At first sip, its impressive how well the alcohol is hidden in this. Does not taste like 11% at all. No more bite, burn, or warmth than youd find in an 8-9% scotch ale. More dry, I guess. Light bitter taste, some sweet. Caramel malt. Kind of peaty. Some light bourbon barrel in the flavor, actually. Some light fruity, herbal hop. Pretty awesome, interesting stuff. Would be interesting to try fresh.. Its good now, but I can only imagine how explosive the flavor mustve been on tap. Cant help but feel that it might be a little faded

Bottle from mikem409, many thanks. split with the wife. Mahogany amber with no head and some floaties. Nose strong of booze and phenols. Hummpf. Taste has strong toffee base and is very boozy. No real notes of dark fruits, bourbon... Or anything to desernable to a scottish ale or  one aged in bourbon barrels. Body is big but creamy: so what. This one misses the target.

Brown/ copper murky color with a rapidly diminishing tan head. Aroma is toffee and booze. Flavor is toffee with some very slight wood and phenolic notes (high alcohols?). Palate is a little bit rough, filling and warm. Nice winter warmer but too heavy and rough.

12 oz. bottle, pours a dark mahogany with a tiny beige head. Aroma of bourbon barrels upfront, along with caramel malts, some dark fruits, whiskey and candied sugar. Flavour brings out sweet caramel malts, booze-less whiskey, moderate bourbon barrels, and a hint of dark dried fruits. Deep layered, very complex, with a perfect accentuation from the barrels, which never dominate. The sweetness is also perfect, not at all cloying. Excellent stuff here.

12oz bottle.  This is an absolute peat bomb both on the nose and taste.  Being a guy who enjoys scotch that is a good thing for me.  Other flavors of sweet malt and slight smoke.  A bit thinner than I would like.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Palate very nice for this one - and I dont usually like this style much. Aroma of booze-sweetened malt and whiskey. Pours clear reddish brown. Some head, ,edium carbonation with pretty thick consistency. Taste is sweet and bitter - good balance. Tap at brewpub.

Bottle from 2012 Winter Solstice.  Pours a dark mahogany color with very little head.  Aroma is very malty and a touch boozy.  Lots of caramel malt with some light barrel notes, vanilla, a touch of smoke.  Taste starts like liquid caramel candy and turns very boozy by the finish.  No alcohol burn but you know this beer is strong.  A little smoke in the finish.  Medium body, slightly sticky mouthfeel.  A solid scotch ale.

Bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.; thanks mikem409). Looks good; a dark amberish-brown with beige lacing.  Smells solid; sweet and malty.  Tastes like it smells, but better, bith the BB characteristics.  Good on the palate.  Good stuff.
Decent brew. High sweetness, the bourbon doesnt really come through at all.
At kuhnhenns. Pours reddish brown some khaki head. Big booze and malt aroma. Taste is sweet and the abv comes through
Thanks to Alex for this growler... dark brown with, amber tint, a light tope head... nose is light, peat, smoke, a bit of caramel, a touch boring... taste is smoked and very scotchy, not bad
On draft at R & H.  Pours a deep maple amber with no head.  Aroma of dark fruit notes, caramel, bread dough and toffee notes.  Taste is much the same as the aroma.
Tap at Rattle for the Kuhnhenn takeover. Pours brown with a bit of tan head. Aroma is mild with some caramel and sweet malt, nutty, earthy. Taste is more of the same, a pretty decent scotch ale.
Draft. Pours brown with a thin head. Sweet malty aroma, with earthy, huskey, toast, and toffee. The flavor has sweet malts, light fleshy fruity notes, toasted breads, and earthy notes. Not bad.
A mahogany pour with off- white lacing. Taste has a complex, smoky scotch undertone that does not take away from the bold nutty flavor

Draft at RnH with Streets, Andrew, and Brendan during the Kuhnhenn Total Tap Takeover Event. Pours a hazy red body with no head. Aroma is light with nice notes of malts, sweet flavors, and smooth earthy tones.
Smooth and silky scotch ale.   Toasted malts and sweet subtle cherry notes. Sessionable and delightful.

bottle thanks to alexsdad.  Pours black with a tan head.  Nose was of sour cherry?  For a Scotch Ale?  Uh oh!  Taste was of peat and malt underneath a prominent sour vinegar.  Dang!  Mouthfeel was super dry, medicinal and carbonated.  Did not taste like a Scotch Ale as it was infected.  Drainpour!  thanks a lot, Kuhnhenn for your crappy QC!

Bottle from TheCheeseMan, thanks! Brown color. Caramel and dried figs in the aroma. Very sweet flavor with apple syrup, dried figs and caramel. Sticky mouthfeel. The sweetness hides the alcohol, but also all other flavors, and is too overwhelming.

December 2008 bottle courtesy of alexsdad06. Thanks! Pours a dark brown color with a thin, persistent head. Decent lacing. Aroma of caramel, nougat, bourbon, wood, faint booze. Taste is caramel, toffee, cherries, leafy hops, very faint bourbon in the finish. Medium bodied.

pours dark brown with creamy beige head..aroma of caramel, molasses, bourbon, chocolate and light hops..a more hoppy flavor profile, with sweet bourbon, caramel, dark fruit and alcohol..another great beer by this brewery

12 oz. thanks, riverside! pours a crystal clear dark brown with very little head, lace, or legs. sweet caramel and graham cracker nose. a little musty to be sure. creamy medium body, mild carb. tangy cereal mid palate, rich sweet grain presence, tons of sweet caramel and graham crackers. mild sweet finish.

12oz bottle from riversideak.  Dark brown with thin off white head.  Leather, cherry, tobacco, and some peat...pretty tart.  Cherry...tart...leather and tobacco in the flavor also.  I would agree that the probably didnt plan this, but this is infected.  Not a drain pour IMHO, bit the medicinal band aid sour is too much.

Holy crap this is infected. Seems that happened to the entire last batch. Nose is sour cherries and caramel, some alcohol. Nice clear deep read with a tan head. Flavor is quite tart and more than a little sour up front with cherry and raspberry being the dominant. Recedes to a big hefty dose of caramel malt and chocolate. Finishes smooth with a bit of astringent sourness. Infected but it actually makes it more interesting than your run of the mill wee heavy. Not to bad... I wonder what the intended beer would have tasted like.

Big thanks to Derek for another Kuhnhenn brew, poured into a tulip.

Pours very, very dark, almost black in the glass.  It shows a deep, hazy copper when held up to the light.  there is a small off-white head that quickly recedes to a solid ring and a soapy swirl on top.  Not much lacing but some boozy legs on the sides.

The aroma is very sweet with the requisite caramel malts and some vanilla, but there is also a healthy dose of dark fruits in the nose and some hints of smoked peat.  The faintest tart cherry whiffs start to come out, but its very faint.  Theres a little alcohol burn in the nose as it warms.

The tart cherries show up early in the taste with an initial pop on the tongue that seems a little out of place.  The sweet dark caramel malt base is definitely still in there as well as some dark fruits, especially raisins and figs.  The finish has a slight smoked peat character but also some lingering sourness.

The mouthfeel is slick and typical of the last couple Kuhnhenn bottles Ive had.  Its not nearly as infected as the Rauch, but its definitely headed that direction.  Im glad I read some of the comments about these beers and caught this one before it really turned.  As it is, its a decent scotch ale that was probably an excellent beer when it was released.

Bottle (Dec 2006 on the lable) at a tasting and so starts a week of palate punishment and "extreme fatigue" though little did I know it at the time. Dirty dark brown. Reddish highlights. No head. Aroma of alcohol and dark fruit; fig, date and raisin. Flavour is winey alcohol. Very sour, only the heavy malt saves it. Underneath the sour and soy is some nice scottish ale trying to come out. Overaged?

Dec 2006 bottle. Murky brown color. Caramel, milk chocolate, boozey sweet nose. More like an Old Ale. Only a touch of peat. Mouth really surprised me with its sourness. Milk chocolate and caramel followed, but the sourness is way too distracting to really like this beer. I am sure it was really good at one point, just not now.

12 oz. bottle from Winter Solstice Dec 2008.  Pours a hay deep copper color with a small fine beige head.  The aroma had a slight sour cherry note that hit just before the caramel malt, toffee, and slight tobacco.  I didnt get the sour cherry when I had this on tap prior to the Solstice party so Im thinking it is slightly infected.  The flavor does not show the sourness as much.  Very slight sour cherry, but dominated by chewy caramel malts, other dark fruits, slight tobacco, and a touch of alcohol as it warms.  Mouthfeel is smooth, but viscous.  This is another beer from Kuhnhenn that has two identities: on tap it is first class and in the bottle you had to drink it early or risk getting something that is infected.  My rating will reflect the combined score from both.

12oz bottle, December 2008 bottling, from alexsdad06--thanks!  Murky brown with a 1/2 finger beige head that faded to a thick ring and thin rather quickly, despite a vigorous pour.  Why does this smell sour?  Another infected Kuhnhenn beer from the Solstice release?  Youre kidding!  Sour cherries and light vinegar are up front in the aroma, with a fair amount of sweet caramel and rancid malts behind.  No bourbon, but I do get a little salty tobacco.  As this warmed up, the sourness did become a little more restrained.  And in the flavor, more restrained yet.  There were some cherries, though more of the fruit sense and not really tangy.  Still plenty of caramel malts, not really too rancid anymore, and the aforementioned salty tobacco.  Light generic chocolate notes are present.  The finish has bitterness around a 2 with not too much of an alcohol burn.  Minimal carbonation with a big thick body.  Big disappointment--no way I can stomach this whole bottle. . .
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 2, 2009 Bottle thanks to polomagnifico!08. Transparent chestnut with a moderate yellow-beige head. Caramel, bourbon, and malt nose, very sweet, and with a hint of wood. Lots of bourbon in the flavor, overriding what could be a nice malt complexity. The tartness others speak of is there as well. Rather thin mouth but coating, a unique finish in some dry wood. Not bad, but Alesmiths Wee Heavy is far superior. Given the weight and overwhelming bourbon notes, this is not an easy drink.

12 oz bottle, Dec 2008.  Murky brown with a beige skin.  Nose is boysenberry, brown sugar and cola.  Full bodied, almost coating, but lightened with tight zesty carb.  Taste is Concord grape, blueberry and toffee.  As it fades, scotch and quinine.  Dry woody finish with tobacco and a touch of bourbon.  Great stuff.

12oz bottle from Hoppymeal - thanks, Derek!!! A translucent amber pour, with a very mild carbonation. Its stillness seems to suggest aged port wine more than anything. The nose is extremely fruity, with some tannins and a modest malt in there as well. The flavor is quite piquant, with leather and wood subtly underpinning the dried fruits and - yeah, I guess - a barely detectable bourbon flavor. Long lingering finish, but theres something about the tartness that just doesnt do it for me.

12oz bottle (thanks Derek for getting this one off my want list!). 2008 Vintage.

After spending a couple hours at Bingo Bash for my little one, I needed something strong to numb the pain so I reached for this one.

Poured a deep and dark orange/amber color, almost brown with a smaller sized off whtie head. Aromas of wood, earthy, peaty, and light bourbon. Tastes of woodiness, bourbon, caramel, dark fruits, brown sugary, vanilla, and toffee. Sweet with a very light dark cherry tart finish. Alcohol content well hidden. I got to say, this one was very nice and Im going to have to get some more!

2008 bottle.  Aroma has notes of dark dried fruits, caramel, and bourbon.  Dark brown hue with a small off white head that fully diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is sweet and malty with a bourbon finish.  Palate is medium/full bodied and soft.  This gives backwards bastard a run for its money.  Fantastic brew.

2006 Vintage 12oz bottle, a gift from Toncatcher for helping him take care of his cherry adam for him, and for that this beer is a nice thank you.  This beer will cement my drunkeness for tonight.  The last review from msante79 seems like a challenge to me.  Pours blackish brown with a tan head.  Nose is big and malty and incredibly decadent.  Taste is sweet and a bit cloying, lots of rich sweet malt, good taste to booze heat ratio.  Gotta say this is pretty damn good, but this has nothing on a well aged Wee Heavy or a cask wee heavy from Alesmith.  That said this is a superb Scotch Ale.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 On tap at Kuhnhenn. Pours beautiful mohagany with beige head. Aroma is great with sweet malt, dark fruits, brown sugar, toffee, chocolate and a little booze. Flavor is thick and complex with sweet malt, dark fruits, brown sugar, toffee, and alcohol warmth comes through in finish. A hell of a scotch ale. Thought is was much more complex than Alesmiths Wee Heavy. I am glad I had the oppertunity to try this brew.

Draft at Kuhnhenns, listed as 10.75% alc., pours a clear dark ruby with brown edges served in a tulip glass, has a one to two finger head of light tan and reddish bubbles, left creamy bubbled lacings on the glass, aromas of dark malt, dark fruit, dark brown sugar and smokey, some malt sweetness, flavor of dark fruit, licorice, dark and/or burnt toffee and dark brown sugar, malt sweetness is present, faint hints of chocolate, alcohol is felt on the first drink, you know this is a 10.75% alcohol ale, little bitterness at the finish but alcohol is felt, alcohol does not take away from the enjoyment of this drink, malt flavors linger after the finish and lingers after the last drink taken from the glass, has a full mouth feel, a very nice scotch ale.

Beautiful reddish mahogany, cloudy topped by a large beige head, uniform and lasting (this is 12.5% mind you!). Upon smelling, you immediately enter the major leagues, there is not so much competition in the scotch ales department, even in a world-wide sense, but this one is an easy chart topper. It may actually be my favourite out of the dozens I’ve tried. Its strong cerealic nose immediately unveils layers upon layers of decadent maltiness. Every whiff opens a new domain of blossoming fruit, while a strong vanilla, peaty, earthy component actually has a real scotch feeling to it. Alcohol warmth is obvious, but you would not advance such a monstrosity as 12+%. The round and fruity body is thick, chewy (not syrupy), rich and an immediate charmer thanks to its cleansing, effective carbonation that leaves you reaching for another sip within an absolutely unreasonable delay. An example with everything, vinous, peaty, fruity, strong and one that keeps you addicted. Just writing the review makes me wish I had one in my hands. Superior scotch ale.

Rating 1200! Growler enjoyed at the VIP tent at the World Beer Festival in Durham. Dark amber pour with thin head.  Full bodied rich mouth-feel.  Heavy roasted flavor upfront.  Dark fruits and caramel round this out. Alcohol is extremely well masked for a 12.5 ABV

Enjoyed at the VIP tent at the World beer Festival in Durham with my partners in crime, drbayern and Celticbrew.
Pours a dark, dark copper with a minimal head and nice lace.  Malty aroma is somewhat sweet.  Has a strong, sweet fruity taste taht calls for sipping, not drinking.  

Definately a highlight!
Deep, dark mahogany pour with little head.  Rich dark fruit and nutmeg aroma with a note of peat.  Cinnamon, raisin, bread, and brandy flavor.  Velvety full body.

Still on tap at Ashley’s.
Very dark red, malty aroma.  Taste is dried fruit, alcohol, wine, grass, and citrus.  But all of these are filtered through a dark roasted screen.  Hard to separate the flavors before the alcohol gets to your taste buds.

On draught at Kuhnhenn, so definitely not retired.  Pours a dark red/brown, with small head.  Mild aroma of malt, sugar, and alcohol.  Strong, sweet, malty taste, very nice.  Rich mouthfeel, nice carbonation.  Very good beer!

OK, this is on tap right now, I don’t think it’s retired, or it’s the 2008 version. I’ve had a few there, brought a growler home to rate. The smell is current/cassis, sweet. The color is dark brown, virtually no head. the flavor is sweet, current/cassis a little honey brown sugar, finishes with a little bitter on the back of the tongue, the body is light and the texture a little syrupy.

Draft sample at MBGF Summer08. Poured a dark brown color with a moderate frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Heavy roasted malt and caremel aroma. Medium  to full body with a sticky texture. Medium to heavy sweet woody flavor with a  medium sweet alcohol finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable brew.

2008 MiBGF: Mahogany hue with a soft beige head and some lace. The aroma has notes of toffee, smoke, prune and dried dates, some heather, and an earthy yeast vapour. The taste is sweet malts and vinous ripened fruits with a noticeable papery oxidized undertone. The finish was moderately spicy and even a tad woody. I am not getting much bourbon however. The mouth feel is very sticky and oily, warming. Seems a tad past it’s prime now, I which I would have had this a year ago.

On tap at HopCat, Grand Rapids. One of the featured brews during Kuhnhenn Week at the bar. Clearish orange-brown body, buff head. Nose of toffee, caramel, and especially candy corn or caramel corn, sweet and sugary. Candy-like body with toffee and hints of banana, vinous notes, and alcohol heat. Well-done, but I wouldn’t want to tackle more than a few ounces.

Best Before 2009 (coming in right below the wire)

A- Pours a murky brownish hue with a very small, tan head.

S- Smells deeply sweet, brown sugar, vinous notes, dark fruit, dates, raisin.

T- Taste is much lighter and sweeter than the nose. Lots of vinous, red wine notes come out, plum, quite a bit of unfermented sugary sweetness towards the end.

M- Has the mouthfeel of a Cabernet at this point. Fairly thick, almost no carbonation. Seems to work well with the flavor.

D- From the nose I was expecting an entirely different beast altogether but this one really suprised me. It has definitely aged well. I would have been interested to see what it tasted like a year and a half ago with more carbonation but the creamy mouthfeel seems to work for this one.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2008 Rerate, draft @ Kuhnhenns.  Pours a dark, clear, slightly viscous cherry-brown color; light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Loads of dried dark fruits (raisins, dates), caramel, and sweet viscous maltiness in the aroma without being cloying.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: loads of sweet caramel, soft brown sugar, and honeyed, dried dark fruits; incredibly dense, generous, and satisfying; nicely earthy hoppiness at the perimeter; very well-composed beer; glad I got to rerate this!  Lengthy finish: toasty malts, dried fruits; lots of toastiness emerging to efface the sweet core. 8.4.8.4.16=4.0

355mL bottle, December 2006, courtesy of ryan.  Thanks!  Pours a dark, murky reddish-brown color; mostly headless; viscous.  A vinegary note upfront that’s definitely out of place; inside, however: viscous raisins and dates; currants, raspberries, chewy maple syrup; like a funkified fruit rollup.  Full mouthfeel: intense, chewy dried red fruits (cherries, raspberries), viscous candy; again, fruit rollups and fruit leather; even with the initial tartness, this is still reasonably pleasant; wish I tried it a year ago.  Long finish: raspberries, dried cherries, and plenty of mildly tart candies and dough. 7.3.7.4.13=3.4

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2009 Bottle from crosling. Fairly clear dark amber with no head. The nose is sugary sweet with lots of dark fruit, toffee, cherries and some oxidation. The flavor is very sweet and lightly tart with cherry, tons of toffee, some oxidation, raisins and prunes. Full body is sticky with moderate carbonation 7/4/6/3/12 = 3.2.........Fresh bottle rerate. Same as previous bottle, minus a bit of the cherry and the tartness. More sweetness in the flavor and nose and a lot more bitterness. A bit better and closer to what I remember having on tap a few years back.

(12oz bottle, 2006 vintage, thanks ryan) Minimal brown head atop lightly hazed mahogany body.  Aroma is sweet, soy, caramel, light oak.  Taste is sweet, infected sourness, caramel/soy, some vanilla/Bourbon, wood.  Sticky full body.  Sad that I didnt get to try this fresh, but it should have aged well but for the infection.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2009 2008. 12oz Bottle. Aroma casts a soft, fireside glow of sherry, light port, and warmed walnut confit. Slightly alcoholic and backed with an aged malt tang. Pours a clear henna-tinted ruby, with little carbonation or head. Flavor is surprisingly bland. The beginnings of vinegar start. A very tangy, alcohol and malt come together at cracker and stilton rind to ride an old horse beyond town limits. Wet. This beer elicts falling rain. This is okay, but its no world-class Scotch Ale. Its got a soppy, old character to it that would be okay if there was heat, depth or expression. But, instead theres just a tired cellar-damp unenthusiasm in this beer. Not as sweet as Id expected. It does finish in a nice brown fruit, fig and toasted grain character. Certainly better than the very old bottle Id previously had, but I can certainly see how this beer can go over the hill fast. Drink this one if youve got it.

Note:Im keeping the written description of my old rating, but its score does not influence the score posted for the beer. The 2006 was just too shot to be a fair rating.
2006. 12oz Bottle. Noses in some aged malt and light oxidation. Light caramel. Faint vinous. Mature. Pours this insidious total murky brown, oily with a fringe in orange. No rim. Flavor is intense. Soy, raisins, cream and dark malt. Tangy from old malt (malt vinegar). Sugar bomb. Oxidized. Tart for no reason at all. Reminds me of this years barleywine. Not drinkable. Dust, old and undrinkable molasses. Ugly. This just isnt drinkable. And I have a hard time believing it ever was. Thanks Sean!

(December 2006 bottle) A sweet Scotch and oak aroma starts this beer off.  It pours a thick muddy brown, with visible sediment and no head at all.  Overwhelming sweetness starts this beer out, with a touch of Scotch in the finish, and a bit of alcohol burn.  There is a bit of tartness present, but the sweetness takes front stage.  Far too sweet for my tastes.

bottle......my first kuhnhenn rating and wont be my last!......aroma: light on the malt interspersed with a modicum of bourbon flavor.  sour notes addes as well.....appearance: just as the commercial discription indicates. barely any head at all.....taste: reminds me more of a flemish sour with tart apple and grape notes accompanied by the light hints of bourbon and caramel malt.  medium body with a boozy/warming finish. malts come throuth a bit more as the beer works its way to room temperature.

Poured a deep golden brown with a very thin head.  the aroma was sweet malty and peaty.  It has that grapey aroma I get from peaty beers.  Some alcohol fumes.  The flavor was short but sweet at the start with a tart middle and finish.  Earthy, peaty and smokey on the finish.  Very warming but not much alcohol on the taste.  Medium to full bodied.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 
Date: May 05, 2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Yankee Go Home!
Appearance: dark muddy brown, scant head
Aroma: sweet bourbon and smokey malt aroma with earthyness
Flavor: rich malt flavor, lots of bourbon and dark caramel, light smokeyness, hint of woody vanilla, tartness in the finish
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4
i was not a fan of this beer.  raisin coloring with a smell of sourness and alcohol.  tastes like sucking on an entire bag of sour patch kids.  no es bueno

A dark brown to black appearance with no head. A sour nose iwth some rotten grapes, alcohol, and chocolate. The flavor is a mix of sour grapes and molasses with some chocolate and coffee present. The finish is cloying and a bit rough. A very odd beer.

Pours a viscous transparent dark mahogany with ruby hues and a thin ring of tan head.  Sweet dark earthy caramel malty aroma has a light fruity tartness and a touch of bourbon oak.  Body starts fairly full with a strange earthy, mildly acidic tartness that seems out of place.  Has a sour, oaky warming finish with some mild oxidation.  Hides its alcohol pretty well but seems almost infected.
Pours a deep mahogany brown with tan head.  Aroma is malty, sour, slightly funky.  Flavor is malty, sour fruit, slightly woody.
This beer is huge.  Just found my rating from the Kuhnhenn winter solstice party in december.  Big and rich, sweet, caramel, brown sugar, rum soaked fruit.  Glad I got a chance to try this one.

Wonderful toffee aroma.  Black wiht a very thin head.  Full palate for a scotch ale.  Lots of really sweet and tangy flavors up front with plenty of caramel/toffee flavors going on.  I dont get any of the 12.5%.  Make sure you let this one warm up plenty--as it let the caramel flavors really shine.  One of the better Kuhnhenn brews Ive had to date, next to KRE and 4th D.

Bottled, big thanks to styles!  Poured a deep, murky brown with maroon highlights.. a ring of beige head remains.  Just a wonderful deep and complex aroma with caramel, brown sugar, sour cherries, and smoky bourbon... very nice presentation.  All of the rich malts showed in the flavor too, but there were off notes of sour cherry skins that threw it off.  Caramel, brown sugar, and cherry tartness accented by sweet bourbon at the warm finish.

Bottle shared at the Columbus Tasting V: Brown orange pour with no head to speak of. Aroma of sweet malts, butter, some peat and booze. Flavors of sweet malt, butterscotch and a bit of peat and smokiness. Medium body with a sweet finsih.

On tap at the Hop Devil Grill, 2/21/07.  dark brown color, chestnut at the edges.  light smoky malt aroma.  flavor is strong bourbon malt, but still pretty mild alcohol heat.  very good job for 12.5%.  dark fruits and a little dry on the finish.  some peaty malt too.

On tap @ HDG.  Dark brown with a trace of tan head. The aroma was full of malty sweetness, caramel, bourbon, and cherries...very inviting. The taste was lovely; huge malt flavor, toffee, caramel, and cherries. The texture was silky and thick...it clung to roof of my mouth. Definitely some alcohol presence in there, but youd never believe 12.5%. There must have been a lot of effort put into this one...what a wonderful treat.

(Bottle, Dec 2006)  Pours a dark burgundy body with a small beige head.  Aroma of sourness, caramel, butterscotch, alcohol burn in the nose, and toasted marshmallow.  Flavor of malt, chocolate, cherry, and molasses.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2009 Tap @ Hop Devil Grill. Stuff is huge. Very deep brown color with a tan head that fades. Aroma is sweet molasses, dark tobacco, raisiny fruityness and tons more that develop when approaching room temperature. The flavor is great. Sticky maltyness with darker notes of tobacco, roasted raisins, grapes, black & elder berries, and loads of maple sweetness. The finish is toasty and warming. A very satisfying and complex brew.

Draught at Coles in Buffalo, NY. Pours a murky dark ruby-brown, almost black, with a small diminishing off-white head. Wonderful aroma of burnt caramel, chocolate and alcohol. Very malty flavour with some burnt caramel, cocoa, dark fruit and alcohol -- delicious. Medium to full bodied, syrupy mouthfeel. What a fantastic Scotch Ale, one of the best Ive ever had.

Tap at Hop Devil Grill.  Deep brown beer with a slightly purple tint buried in it.  Wonderfully deep sweet fruity aroma, dried plums, dates and figs and some lightly apple and raisin notes as well.  Flavour is also quite sweet but just manages to stay balanced.  Chewy texture, raisins, dates, and plums with a soft raspberry/cherry fruitiness as well.  Soft vineous character on the back.  Sweet chewy palate but very tasty.

Draft at Kuhnhenn strong ale fest, Hop Devil. Super-thick. Rich molasses in the flavor, almost overwhelming. Slight hops and fruit. Aroma is pretty thin and lacking... overall, big and tasty, but unrefined and blunt and hard to drink.

Tap at HDG - dark purplish red color, with a large, creamy head - sweet aroma of dark fruits, with light smoke/burnt hints - rather sweet, with apparent alcohol, but the richness of the flavor almost completely makes up for this - dark fruit, cocoa, caramel, vanilla - no real notes of wood exactly, but there is an earthiness to it that might be from the wood - no indication of boubon-aging - just a bit too sweet, but very tasty.

On tap at HDG. Deep dark copper in color with a nice dark head. Malty and fruity aroma. Caramel and fig and raisin notes. Malty chocolatety and cherry like flavor. Oak notes. Smooth tasting. Thick mouthfeel. Finish is malty. Nice alcohol burn. Well balanced beer. Full bodied.  Very nice beer. Well done.

Courtesy of Hopscotch. Thanks Eric. Poured into my newly acquired Planet Hollywood thistle picked up at my local thrift shop. I like the thistle. Its good for smelling.  And this beer is a smeller. Big ol aroma begging to have a nose stuck in it.  I got a lot of carmel malts, raisins, plums, moonshine cherry cordials, caramelized sugar, a little oak and bourbon.  Dark brown body with a tan lacing. Syrupy and thick mouthfeel with more fruits, definately cherry and raisins there at the beginning with a little plum in the finish. Burly and strong. This is a big, well balanced beer.  This is not to say you cant taste a good bit of alchohol. Was thinking about aging this one but wanted to get another Kuhnhenn under the belt.   Hopefully I can get another and age it for a few years. I have a feeling this will be very nice in a couple years.

Courtesy of Ibrew2or3. Thanks, Dave. The aroma is a massive wave of caramel, chocolate and malts with a slightly aged barleywine note of oxidation.  The body is black/brown with red tint and quite still looking, proffering no head. Concentrated chocolate flavor on the first sip followed by perfumey alcohol, mild peat, cherry and other fruits, caramel and at times hints of darker fruits like raisin and plum. Very concentrated and very heady.

On tap at the Barleywine fest at Coles.  This was far and away my favorite of the day, darker than any of the other offerings, almost a porter feel.  Dark head that stayed with the beer the whole time, dark, robust.  Im taking my growler down for a fillup of this while its still available.  Great, great flavor and worth the entire day.  You wont find this many places, and for that I feel especially fortunate to be in the right place at the right time.  Superb.  My best beer of the year.

12er.  Extremely dark brown.  Sweet dark fruits, caramel and chocolate are present in the awesome nose.  Amazing, multi-dimensional flavor, which is wonderfully fruity, a bit smoky, awfully caramelly and extremely complex.  I dont taste any wood, in fact, I wonder if this bottling was even aged in wood, but I dont care.  Its fantastic.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2007 Dark and somewhat ruddy mahogany pour. Immediately and totally dissipating off white head, leaving a thin ring of minimal lacing. Some peaty and smoky malts lead the way in the aroma, in reserved fashion. Heaping caramel malt, apparent alcohol, and fruits indentifiable as plums, raisins, cherries and blackberries round out the nose. Very complex fruits. Flavor is just awesome. Were it not for the alcohol butting in, this could be a magnificent high gravity daily drinker, taste wise. Notes of chocolate pudding, booming smokiness, burnt toast, and a pounding caramel malt component drive the flavor forward. Finish is all caramel. The palate is pretty smooth but seems unorganized. Otherwise a fine treat. Thick and sticky would be an understatement.

Draught.  At Coles in Buffalo.  Holy fin s**t this was a dark Scotch Ale - looked like a stout - thick reddish-brown, opaque with an average tan head ("the colour of dried blood" said my nephew of his pint) - if this were a stout or porter, it would get 4/5.  The smell was strongly of burnt caramel malt, yeast and mucho cereal grain, moderately boozy - smelled a lot like a malty creme brulee.  Taste - VERY yummy - dark burnt caramel malt, strong coffee, creme brulee, the alcohol started strong and finished very strong - but excellent;  what a treat.  Thick, sticky, sweet-syrupy body, slightly astringent, thick boozy/malt mouthfeel, slightly burnt aftertaste - bloody excellent, well done.

Tap @ Coles.  Deep ruby, no head.  Nose is malt, non-acidic balsamic, very slight alcohol, a hint of grape soda.  Quite rich and sweet.  Flavor is rich malt, sweet balsamic, earthy/meaty sweetness, caramel.  Finish is caramel & fruit (more of that balsamic going on here)  A wonderful synthesis of a scotch ale and a barleywine.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2007 Thanks to styles for the bottle!  Not a real big fan of scotch ales, but this beer was really good.  Lots of sweet sugars, vanilla, caramel. A nice and warming presence of alcohol, but it doesnt get overbearing.  A nice and sticky palate.  This beer was very enjoyable.

Bottle shared at Columbus Tasting V - Pours Dark brown with no head at all.  Aromas of caramel, lots of alcohol, and a little smoke.  Flavor is big of caramel malts, some bourbon, brown sugar and vanilla and some alcohol.  Full bodied and smooth with low carbonation.

Tap.   Pours a dark ruby-brown color with a faint tan colored head that settles out.   Aroma is caramel, sweet malt, peat.   Flavor is sweet malt, light bourbon, caramel, burnt sugar, vanilla.   Palate is full bodied, mild carbonation, sweet, resinous finish.   Exceptional!

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2007 12oz goblet @ Coles Buffalo, NY. My first experience with Kuhnhenn. Almost a bourbony red wine aroma. Sweet, malty & alcohol. Deep dark brownish in color.Burbon slightly present in first taste. Expecting more of a bourbon burn but not there. Sweet & sticky, smoooth with little to no carbonation & dangerous. Nice if I smoked cigars. Would be tough to enjoy a couple.

Had on tap at the brewery after a long night of drinking and it took a little while to warm up to. Aroma had a lot of sweetness with  a little bit of smokiness and caramel in the aroma. Good body, little alcohol burn. Sticky mouthfeel but still really good. Didnt really get that much bourbon.

Duane shared this bottle from the holiday gift pack with me.  Pours a very dark and murky brown color.  Tons of caramel and vanilla in the nose.  Earthy malts, caramel, oak, subtle vanilla flavors, hints of bourbon.  They did a great job of not aging this in the barrel for too long.  Very low carbonation, insanely smooth and easy drinking.  Not even a hint of alcohol in the finish.  Ive been enjoying scotch ales more and more lately and this was a real treat.  Thanks to Duane for sharing and Styles for picking this up for us.

12 oz. bottle, my first foray into the Kuhnhenn Holiday gift pack, picked up by Styles as part of a recent trade.  shared the bottle with illini08.  
looks almost black, but when held up to the light I realize its more of a dark brown with a ruby edge, very fast fading tan head.  this is one super sweet caramel monster of a beer!  nose is bourbon, oak, some vanilla, caramel  and toffee.  flavor is more of the same with some hints of dark dried fruit.  mouth-feel is very thick and sticky sweet on the lips.  wheres the alcohol?  theres no hint of it until late.  outstanding!  thanks Chris.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 On draft at brewery. Pours dark and roasty in color with thin off white head. Sitting there still and un-assuming in front of me it looks like a black cup of coffee in a clear glass. The aroma is simply HUGE with sweet rich caramel yummy-ness and hints of coffee. The taste. Wow, this is good. Rich deep caramel syrup. Lots of caramel. There are also undertones of dark fruit dates and cherries soaking in a caramel bath. Nice! Some chocolate also bleeds through the vail of caramel-ness from time to time. I love this beer. No sense of ABV.

Draft... Murky, very dark ale with a mid-sized, creamy, beige head. The  nose is vinous with lots of blackstrap molasses, peat smoke, caramel malt, chocolate, coffee and diacetylic butter. Vinous, sweet flavor. Chocolate, coffee, port, dark fruits, moderately bitter bourbon and hops. Full-bodied and silky with moderate carbonation. Finishes chocolaty, bittersweet and warming.

On tap at the pub: Oily dark brown pour with almost no head. Aroma of soy, some alcohol, and dark roasted malts. Flavor, molassas, some chocolate, alcohol. Thick oily mouthfeel, a little hot, but pretty good.
On tap at Kuhnhenn.Sweet malt aroma.Pours dark with a slight tan head.Get some dark fruits in the flavor.Medium body with a sweet alcohol finish.

On tap:  Malty raison, caramel, banana bread and Bourbon.  Pours a somewhat transparent reddish-brown .  Small off-white head.  Flavors of raison, caramel, brown sugar and only light alcohol.  Rather sweet.  A little cloying.

draft at the brewpub--deep burgundy.  smells sweet, and of fruits, most particularly raspberry.  very sweet and sticky, malty.  lingering bitterness in the finish.  very interesting beer, and i never would have guessed that it was hiding a brisk 12.5% alcohol.

Draft: Cloudy brick. Tight-bubbled light beige foam. Rooty, liquefied fig aroma with caramelized banana, spicy alcohol, vanilla, and earthy malts. Very vinous and leafy with faint toast. Thick, slippery body. Mostly still. Truckload of meaty malts curb the initial leafy twang. Acidity muffles the sweetness with a blast of steeped overripe plums. Slightly medicinal, as well, with a surprisingly tame bourbon character. Sharp tannins continually underlie the soured fruit acidity. Lengthy plummy malt finish touched with vanilla and black cherry subtleties. Overall, less acidity and more velvety carbonation would deaden some of the acidity and better enhance the lushness of the malts. Great stuff, though.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: draught.  thick off white head.  great bourbon aroma.  sweet taste with mix of fruits and bourbon.  must try.

Hooo boy.  I tried this one on my first visit to Kuhnhenns, during an extended lunch break from work.  It looks beautiful: A deep, dark red-black color with a small head.  That head was probably being chased away by the rich caramel and scotch aromas that were coming up from below.  Its sweet and hot, the scotch taking command of the affair.  You dont drink this beer, it drinks you.  I could never drink more than one of these per visit to Kuhnhenns but I will be sure to get one every time.

I dont consider myself to be a conoisseur of Scotch ales-not by any means. But I wish I wouldve had a better opportunity to taste the qualities of what makes a Scotch ale so wonderful with this beer. There was a LOT of bourbon that crowded out most of the toasted malty character. It was quality bourbon though, I could distinguish the tangy and sugary notes that deepened the ale, adding body (and alcohol) while not making it over the top.Maple syrup notes and a lingering bitterness. Enjoyable malty finish. I wish I could taste this non-bourbon aged.

On tap at the brewery.  Dark brown in color with almost no head, but it was white while it was there.  A sweet carmely soy sauce smell.  A winey/vanilla/cherry taste.  Lots of other flavors that I could not make out.  Reminded me a lot of a finely aged Sam Adams Triple Bock.

On tap.  Wow.  This is a terrific brew.  Deep black.  Thick appearing  Large off white to tan head lingers.  This stuff is viscous!  Aroma is malty, the notes from the bourbon subtly make an appearance.  Perhaps some smokey notes.  Taste is very complex.  That means I cant make alot out of it.  Definately malty, some peat, bourbon notes.  Hops seem to be understated but present. Very good beer.

from the tap at the brewery. poured dark brown with a tan head. aroma malts, licorice a hint of vinergar, alcohol. flavor this was a kick in the rear with the alcohol got caramel, honey, choc. at 1st I wasnt impressed the alcohol was to strong but as the beer warmed it just got better. another good one
2004 Great Taste of the Midwest. Dark red/orange body, tan head. A sweet malty licorice aroma with a big vinous licorice taste. Hints of bourbon and oak. Qutie a big beer, a bit overwelming at times.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2004 2004 draft.  Oh boy.  Starts out with a deep blackish-brown color, almost purplish.  Small off white head.  Aroma is sweet, brown sugar, rich caramel malt, light hints of bourbon, a bit of alcohol detectable and plenty of raisins and dark chocolate.  Flavor begins with a huge powerful body that sticks to the palate and is quite creamy.  The bourbon barrel aging adds a bittersweet element in the background that is subtle yet detectable enough to taste quite pleasant.  Lots of vanilla flavors, caramel and what hit me as a coconut flavor, weird but thats what I thought I tasted.  Warming on the finish, but never would I think this is 12.5.  Smooth and creamy, but perhaps a bit of a soy sauce (acidity from the barrel, combined with huge caramel malt dominance).  The mouthfeel, as far as its velvety, rich texture is concerned, deserves a 5, but the balance is way off.  Its sour, then sweet, then alcoholic.  Its not terribly cohesive.  A bit fatiguing at the end of the glass.
